displayed_text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that? Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: of just the stuff. Healthcare Professional: Oh yeah. There’s you know some other areas some lymph nodes are slightly enlarged, Patient: Right. Doctor: they’ve gotten a little bit bigger. Your PSA has gone up just a little bit too. So I think… Patient: What’s a little bit? Healthcare Professional: Your last one was thirty one point seven a week ago it was twenty six. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So there’s a little bit of progression there that maybe… Doctor: It’s a movement you know. Healthcare Professional: …we’ll do something different for you. Okay. Doctor: Yeah so I’m thinking we’re always trying to not be behind. Patient: Right, right..

Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. They took blood last time, and ran some protocols and you were going to check on some numbers. Doctor: Anything new on your body that you’ve noticed that you want me to take a look at? Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five.

Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____. Family Member: It’s just what bothers me about it is the pain that sometimes he go through. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Sometimes the pain can be a ten and then sometimes the pain can be a four. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If he had a four, I’d be comfortable with him being on the bike – Doctor: Yeah, I know.

Patient: Don’t hesitate to Doctor: Yeah. Oh, I know, I know, I know. I know, I know. Patient: I mean --- Family Member: So Patient: I understand some people Doctor: And, you know, that’s a test also they could just do on their own. They can go to web site and order the test. Patient: Right, right, exactly. Doctor: They don’t need a doctor to do it. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So.

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: Just the catheters. Family Member: Because he was improving; results were uh coming in. You know kidneys back into you know. Patient: They were getting better everyday, yeah. Doctor: They adjusted your blood pressure medicine. Patient: Correct. That is one thing that they did. They said the first time it was not good for the kidneys. Family Member: Actually when you came out it was two point two. And then a week later we went to see his uh - Patient: General practitioner and - Family Member: So what is the reading today? Doctor: One point zero. Family Member: Wow! Doctor: So that is what it’s supposed to be. A new one. (background noise persists in addition to keyboarding sounds)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’. Patient: But will I – wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, but Dr. P_ just talked about one bag! And you come out with two bags, man! Doctor: Well, you might need two bags. Patient: Woooooooo. Doctor: Where’s the bowel gonna get re-routed? It’s gotta poop somewhere, and you’re got a connection. Patient: Wooooooo. Doctor: It’s two bad organs.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That might take a minute. Patient: Okay. Family Member: In addition to the radium or that? Doctor: No, that is the radium. Patient: Oh, that is the radium. Doctor: Yeah. So, there’s different names.

Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them. Patient: Yeah. That does help. Family Member 1: So, okay. Family Member 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take? Family Member 1: Like 10? Doctor: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter. Family Member 2: Mhmm.

Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial –

Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: Um. So, let me, uh, check in with I_ to see if she needs to follow with you, uh, because we’ll just stay on drug for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I put the order in for the blood test. I need to just check to make sure that, with the holiday, that if I draw it, it’s not gonna get lost or be not usable because, uh, nobody’s here to work on it. Patient: Right. Doctor: They only run the test once a week. So, if they’re aware it’s coming today and they run it next Monday, then you’re golden. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. If that’s positive, then that would be this one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if it’s negative, it could be that one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or, if it was positive, you could still do that one. Um.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: He tells me every time you see him once a month because he draws blood work and everything so then I know you pop up in my systems like oh, you’re in the systems. So, if there’s issues though like things that aren’t going right and you feel whatever, you tell him but then you could always come back to see me anytime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m just gonna put, I’m trying to think, am I giving you the shot or is that your neurologist? Who’s giving you the Lupron? Patient: You are. Doctor: So, you’d have to come back anyways. Did you get a shot today or are you coming? Patient: No, we got one last uh two weeks. Doctor: So, we’ll figure out when your next one is and you’ll come back for that for sure Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then just know you can call anytime and come back in between. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: And then the chemo we’ll just push back but just know it’s around.

Patient: That’s normal to buy a new car, yeah. Doctor: Who wants to pay that insurance, too? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so now we will probably move you guys to Wednesday, Tuesday or Wednesday. Which day would you prefer? Family Member: You pick. Patient: Wednesday’s fine. Family Member: Wednesday. Doctor: So we’ll do, the tenth will be his next treatment. Healthcare Professional: I’ll take it out to K___ out front there so she can get scheduled right - Family Member: Do we come here? Healthcare Professional: No, you’ll get labs at regular lab, go to clinic and then head to the regular infusion area. Where you usually saw Dr. F_____ right across there, the ___ clinic. Family Member: Oh yeah, okay.

Patient: About my voice. All right. Huh, I . Do you think that’ll help? Doctor: Huh, like liquid-? Patient: So it’s not sore. Doctor: Like liquid saliva? Patient: No. That huh, what do they call it? Kaopec something. It’s chlo, chlo, chlo. Doctor: Chloraseptic? Patient: Yeah. Chloraseptic. Doctor: That might help. Or when you’re at the drugstore picking up your ibuprofen, there’s liquid saliva. Okay? So like you have the liquid tears. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: There’s artificial saliva. So that if this side of your mouth isn’t making the saliva, you can put some of that in, and just moisten it up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Family Member: Any other tests that we need to know about? Blood work and bone biopsy? Doctor: That’s all what I can think of right now. Healthcare Professional: and recent scans. Doctor: Yeah the scans are pretty recent so we should be able to use those. Family Member: With this – so with this new regime would he get the CAT scan bone scan and stuff sooner than six months?
DOC Probably oh yeah, yes. Definitely sooner than six months. It’s between eight to twelve weeks. And that’s all in this protocol we’re gonna read? And is that still N__ or R__ or no more N__ or R__ … Doctor: Well they will be from here so she will bring you the copy of the consent. Today you’re just taking the copy to read. But uh no then it will be S__ is the downtown person. I think you may have met her. Family Member: We met S___, yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: And we stay in S__’s study? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: The patient… Doctor: You can yeah. As long as until you say no or I say no. (Laughs) Family Member: No I mean we’re happy to help so.
